awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: WERF: GOALI: Bioaugmentation-Enhanced Anammox for Mainstream Nitrogen Removal
awd_abstract_narration:
Field
1705674

Nutrient nitrogen (N) in excess is a major pollutant affecting the environment and public health; consequently, excess N must be removed from wastewater (WW). Conventional nutrient N-removal technology relies on a sequence of two microbial process known as nitrification-denitrification. The first step (nitrification) involves the oxidation of ammonium to nitrate. The drawback is that nitrification requires a large input of energy to aerate the water. The second step (denitrification) involves the reduction of nitrate to harmless elemental nitrogen gas. The drawback is that valuable chemical energy is required for the nitrate reduction that could be better used to make biofuels such as methane-rich biogas. Improvements in the economy of nutrient N-removal can be achieved with anaerobic ammonia oxidizing (anammox) bacteria. Anammox converts nitrite and ammonium to elemental nitrogen gas without any need for aeration or chemical energy. As a technology anammox must be combined with partial aeration to form nitrite from about half of the ammonium (partial nitritation), but this process saves 57% of the aeration costs and 100% of the chemical energy demand compared to conventional nutrient N-removal.

Anammox has become a mature technology for the treatment of high ammonium, low organic matter WW, exemplified by sludge liquor side streams from the dewatering of anaerobically digested sludge, which accounst for 15-30% of the N load at wastewater treatment plants (WWTP). The objective of this research is to apply anammox to the 70-85% of the N-load in the mainstream of a WWTP. The strategy proposed is based on utilizing highly active anammox sludge cultivated on the ammonium rich side stream with an upflow anaerobic sludge blanket (UASB) reactor to bioaugment another UASB treating the mainstream. The reactors will be operated as a single-stage partial-nitritation anammox process by introducing substoichiometric quantities of elemental oxygen via aeration. The intellectual merit of the proposed work is to convert the liability of the high N-loading embodied by the ammonium rich side stream into an asset for biological N-removal for the mainstream. The key scientific/engineering question is whether bioaugmentation of highly enriched anammox sludge can be used to enhance the N-treatment process in the mainstream where conditions are less favorable for growing and sustaining anammox due to competition from heterotrophic bacteria and low N concentrations. The PIs will explore a novel stratification of partial nitritation and anammox in the microaerophilic exterior and anoxic interior of the same sludge particles, respectively. Through kinetic, metabolic and metagenomic/transcriptomic analyses, the PIs will determine whether the enriched anammox sludge deteriorates in mainstream by providing biomarkers to quantitatively monitor the anammox bacteria they contain.  They will also obtain information on the shifting composition and function of the microbial population. The project directly addresses the National Academy of Engineering grand challenge of improving the management of the N cycle by developing energy saving technology to control the load of excess nutrient-N into the environment.  Two PhD students will be working with the GOALI partner at the regional wastewater reclamation facility to gain industrial experience.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Anaerobic ammonium oxidation (anammox) is a newly discovered microbial process in which nitrite combines with ammonium to form benign dinitrogen gas. The process can be utilized to remove nutrient nitrogen from wastewater. The treatment of nutrient-nitrogen is more efficient with anammox compared to the conventional nitrification-denitrification process. Anammox provides savings by lowering aeration costs. The objective of this research was to determine if the anammox biomass produced from treating concentrated ammonium waste streams can be used to treat ammonium in dilute domestic wastewater (“main stream”) with its associated high organic substrate content. The effect of organic constituents, represented by acetate, was studied in two parallel run anammox moving bed biofilm reactors (MBBR) of 3.7 L each. One of the reactors was the treatment reactor which received increasing concentrations of acetate. The other reactor was the control reactor which did not receive acetate. 

Intellectual Merit. Overall, a duality in reactor performance was observed due to acetate addition. On the one hand, low acetate concentration increased the total nitrogen removal (TNR). This was due to complete removal of the anammox substrates, nitrite and ammonium, combined with the removal of nitrate (a minor byproduct of the anammox process) that was potentially consumed by the heterotrophic/denitrifying bacteria enriched in the culture. While, on the other hand, increasing the acetate concentration decreased the TNR. This was attributed to the decline in the ammonium removal, since high organic substrate loading promoted denitritation, thereby removing nitrite, that would be needed to enable ammonium removal. The results also demonstrated a high resiliency of the anammox process. Following the period of maximum acetate dosage, the acetate caused inhibition of the anammox reaction, there was a rapid recovery of the anammox process when the acetate dosage was lowered again. This indicates that the anammox process can tolerate intermittent exposures to organic substrates. A metagenomic analysis indicated that the dominant anammox bacterium from the MBBR was found to be an anammox bacterium, Brocadia caroliniensis, 27% of the reads mapped to it. A large fraction of the remaining metagenome assembled genomes (MAG) which accounted for 7.7% to 0.25% of the reads belonged to the phylum Chloroflexota. Members of Chloroflexota are known to consume glucose and N-substituted sugars (N-acetyl-glucosamine) under anoxic conditions. There are 6 MAGs in the metagenome that contain members of Anaerolineae that commonly co-exist in anammox enrichment culturess. It is hypothesized that Anaerolineae consume cellular byproducts produced by anammox bacteria.

Broader Impacts. The anammox enrichment culture was found to catalyze the biotransformation of pyrazole and triazole, causing their conversion to 3 amino-azoles. The results suggest that the anammox enrichment culture can be useful in degrading emerging contaminants. Anammox bacteria are autotrophic which is curious since the bioreactor results and metagenomic results indicate that multiple bacteria in the anammox enrichment are potentially heterotrophic. Potentially this observation is a clue indicating that autotrophic metabolism during primary succession can produce organic matter (e.g,. exopolysaccharides). The organic matter derived from the cellular material eventually leads to a diverse heterotrophic population, during later stages of microbial succession.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Jim A Field

    Nivrutti Lakhey
    Public Domain
    Jim A Field
